questions.text: A 25-year-old male came with complaints of acute abdominal pain. A plain X-ray abdomen erect was taken which is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pneumoperitoneum

The above X-ray clearly shows the presence of subdiaphragmatic free gas in the right upper quadrant.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of a road traffic accident. The finding in the axial CT image is as shown below. It is most commonly caused due to bleeding from
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Middle meningeal artery

The given CT image shows the typical bi-convex hyperdense lesion not crossing cranial sutures, characteristic of an extradural hemorrhage. It is most commonly due to bleeding from the middle meningeal artery. As the dura mater tends to adhere to the skull, the hematoma collecting between the skull and this dura is seen on CT sections as a biconvex dense area immediately beneath the skull vault, convex towards both the brain and the vault. They tend not to cross the suture lines.

questions.text: Identify the artery marked by red arrow.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Superior mesenteric artery

The artery marked by the red arrow is the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), which gives rise to various branches that supply the small intestines, cecum, ascending, and part of the transverse colon.

The CT also depicts nutcracker syndrome, a left renal vein entrapment syndrome characterized by extrinsic compression of the left renal vein (marked by a red arrow), most commonly between the abdominal aorta and superior mesenteric artery. This syndrome is one of the postulated reasons for left- sided varicoceles being more common than the right side.

questions.text: A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is seen on the MRI. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Craniopharyngioma

A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is suggestive of craniopharyngioma. It is derived from Rathke’s pouch and arises near the pituitary stalk, commonly extending into the suprasellar cistern.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Chronic calicific pancreatitis

As the given image shows, there are multiple calcifications within the region of the pancreas, which is characteristic of chronic calcific pancreatitis.

This condition results from long-standing inflammation of the pancreas, leading to the deposition of calcium. Chronic pancreatitis is often associated with alcohol abuse, genetic factors, or recurrent acute pancreatitis. The calcifications are a hallmark feature and help differentiate it from other abdominal pathologies.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presented with seizures and her radiological image is as given below. Knowing that the MR spectroscopy of the lesion showed elevated choline, alanine, and lactate, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Neurocysticercosis

The given radiological image and history of seizures suggests a diagnosis of neurocysticercosis.

Neurocysticercosis presents with seizures, hydrocephalus, raised ICP, and may even cause signs of chronic meningitis. The given image shows multilobulated cystic lesions (with scolex) in the subarachnoid space, typical parenchymal brain calcifications are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by T. solium (Cysticercosis cellulose).

questions.text: The pelvic ultrasound of a 35-year-old woman is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Monochorionic twins

The pelvic ultrasound in a 35-year-old woman shows the ‘T-sign’ seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy.

In monochorionic pregnancy, the chorion does not extend between the layers of the intertwin membrane. Thus, the inter-twin membrane comes to an abrupt halt in a T-configuration at the edge of the amniotic sac.

In contrast, in a dichorionic pregnancy, the sonographic image depicts a ‘twin-peak’ sign or the ‘lambda sign” as the chorion is present between the intertwin membrane. A triangular portion of the placenta is seen inserted between the amniochorion layers.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of fatigue and difficulty in swallowing for the past few months. On examination, she has pallor, angular stomatitis, and a bald tongue. There is no history of weight loss. Her hemoglobin level is 9 g/dL and a peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia. A barium swallow shows the following findings. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Plummer-Vinson syndrome

The above clinical and laboratory findings along with the barium swallow showing an esophageal web suggest a diagnosis of Plummer-Vinson syndrome. Plummer-Vinson syndrome, also known as Patterson-Kelly-Brown syndrome, refers to a triad of iron deficiency anemia, dysphagia, and the presence of an esophageal web. These patients present with anemia, dysphagia, glossitis, angular stomatitis, koilonychia, etc. The iron deficiency is thought to cause mucosal injury during swallowing which forms a web during the process of healing. The post-cricoid region sustains the maximum trauma during swallowing, and so this is the most common site of web formation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman has the following flow pattern of umbilical arteries on a Doppler study. What does this pattern indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Normal diastolic flow

The given Doppler image indicates normal diastolic flow in the umbilical arteries. Umbilical artery vessels are characterized by forward, low-resistance flow. As gestation increases, there is a gradual fall in all the resistance Indices, so the amount of forward diastolic flow increases. S/D ratio decreases as the period of gestation increases (S represents the peak systolic flow or velocity, and D indicates the end-diastolic flow or velocity).

questions.text: In patients with pneumonia, what is the most common causative organism that can lead to this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Staphylococcus aureus

The chest x-ray depicts a pneumatocele adjacent to the left heart border (black arrow in the image below). The most common cause of pneumatocele formation is Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with thunderclap headaches and seizures. There is no history of trauma. Non-contrast CT was done and is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Subarachnoid hemorrhage

The clinical features of a thunderclap headache and seizures with the given CT scan showing hyperdense areas corresponding to blood in the subarachnoid basal cisterns suggest a diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is the bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. It usually occurs due to bleeding from a ruptured aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation. Most of the ruptured aneurysms are located at the circle of Willis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a 1-week history of low-grade fever and progressive chest pain. Chest X-ray revealed the following. Considering the symptoms and imaging, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pericardial effusion

The given image shows a globular enlargement of the cardiac shadow, called the money bag appearance. Considering the above symptoms and the chest X-ray findings, the most likely diagnosis is pericardial effusion.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with chronic alcoholism presented with severe right-sided upper abdominal pain. On examination, her SOFA score was 3. An abdominal CT was done which is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Emphysematous cholecystitis

The given clinical scenario along with the CT showing gas within the wall of the gallbladder is suggestive of emphysematous cholecystitis.
Emphysematous cholecystitis is a rare form of acute cholecystitis where gallbladder wall necrosis causes gas formation intramurally or intraluminally.

This condition occurs most frequently in elderly males or patients with diabetes, Secondary infection of the gallbladder wall with gas-forming organisms such as Clostridium welchii/ C. perfringens leads to emphysematous cholecystitis, and aerobes such as Escherichia coli may also be isolated. Patients present with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever. Crepitus is present on physical examination.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cervical rib

The given X-ray shows cervical rib.

Patients with a cervical rib usually show a lump and tenderness in the supraclavicular fossa. The pallor and paresthesias are due to vascular and neural compressions respectively. A radiograph of the neck is useful in detecting a cervical rib

questions.text: A two-day-old neonate with abdominal distension and failure to pass meconium underwent a barium enema study, as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hirschsprung’s disease

The given clinical scenario and the barium enema showing a dilated right colon, with a transition zone in the mid-descending colon, are together suggestive of Hirschsprung disease.

The most important sign on barium enema is a sudden change of calibre from the narrow aganglionic segment and dilated proximal bowel.
Hirschsprung disease is characterized by aganglionosis (absence of ganglion cells) in the distal colon and rectum. This may occur due to the failure of neuroblasts in neural crest cells to migrate into bowel segments or the degeneration of already migrated neuroblasts. Hence, functional obstruction develops as a result of a spasm in the denervated colon

questions.text: Given below is the CT abdomen of a patient who presented with diarrhea. He is most likely to be suffering from
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pseudomembranous colitis

The CT image depicts the accordion sign seen in pseudomembranous colitis.

Clostridium difficle infection (CDI) commonly caused by the disruption of the commensal colonic microflora, due to prolonged antimicrobial use, especially antibiotics like cephalosporins, ampicillin, clindamycin, and fluoroquinolones. The more severe form of CDI is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC).

Toxigenic Clostridium difficile produces toxin A (an enterotoxin) and toxin B (a cytotoxin), damaging the epithelial-cell barrier function and causing diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation, which initially appear as small whitish-yellow plaques and later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. The patient also presents with fever, abdominal pain, and leukocytosis.

questions.text: The following spot film was taken while performing a voiding cystourethrogram for a 2-year-old girl. Which of the following investigations will be useful for the evaluation of renal scarring in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tc 99m DMSA

The given voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) shows a unilateral grade 4 vesicoureteric reflux (VUR). The investigation of choice to evaluate for renal scarring in reflux nephropathy is the Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) scan.

It Is used in renal imaging to evaluate renal structure and morphology, particularly in paediatric imaging for the detection of scarring and pyelonephritis. DMSA is an ideal agent for the assessment of the renal cortex as it binds within the proximal tubules of the cortex with longer retention”than other agents.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old patient presents with progressive difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for 8 months. A barium swallow was done and is shown in the image below. What other investigations should be done to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?

UGIE- Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy

PET- Positron emission tomography
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

UGIE + manometry

The given clinical scenario and the barium swallow showing bird beak sign are suggestive of achalasia cardia. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (UGIE) and manometry should be done to confirm the diagnosis.

Achalasia is a motility disorder and is less common. It typically presents as dysphagia for solids and liquids. Other features such as regurgitation and chest pain are also present.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with severe back pain, vomiting, and hypotension. CT findings are given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Renal angiomyolipoma

The given CT image shows well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in colour) that indicate fatty tissue. This is suggestive of renal angiomyolipomas.

Angiomyolipomas (AMLs) are benign tumours that occur sporadically or in association with tuberous sclerosis. It is commonly seen in adults between 30 and 50 years of age, with a female predilection. AMLS predominantly affect the kidneys, though they can occur in other sites such as the liver (a common extra-renal location) and less frequently in the ovary, fallopian tube, spermatic cord, palate, and colon.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the non-contrast CT scan of a patient given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hydatid cyst

The given CT image shows a cyst in the liver with the serpent sign and areas of calcification, which are suggestive of hydatid disease.
Hydatid disease or echinococcosis is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species of flatworms. Its life cycle consists of dogs as definitive hosts and humans as accidental intermediate hosts.

Primary hydatid cysts most commonly occur in the liver. Most patients are asymptomatic but when symptomatic, the patient presents with hepatomegaly, pain, and obstructive jaundice.
